explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_liquids.rationale: It was classified as Category 2 (GHS acceptance criteria: flash point being less than 23 degC, and initial boiling point being more than 35 degC) for 2 degC of flash point and 88.5 degC of initial boiling point.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Not classified because of UNRTDG Class: 3

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen (but not chlorine and fluorine) chemically bonded only to carbon (but not to other elements).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Category 5 based on SPECIES: Rat; ENDPOINT: LD50;VALUE:3000 mg/kg; REFERENCE SOURCE: ACGIH (7th, 2003)

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on rabbit dermal LD50 = 20mL/kg or more (RTECS (2005)) and 20000mg/kg or more (IUCLID (2000)), it was set as the outside of Category.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Since 1 out of 6 rats died with 16000ppm, and 5 out of 6 rats died with 32000ppm (ACGIH (7th, 2003)). It was thought that LC50 by inhalation of vapor was larger than 16000 ppm, and it was classified as out of Category.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: There are statements that there is a possibility of becoming a cause of dryness, rednesses, cracks, and "severe" chemical burn on humans (ACGIH (2003), ICSC (1998), HSFS (2004)). But according to the result of Draize examination (skin application of 500mg) on rabbit, it was "mild" (ACGIH (7th, 2003)). And since it was thought that there was no irreversible disorder, it was classified as Category 2.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: There is a statement that stimulativeness of the eye is carried out in humans and it can become a cause of redness or a chemical burn (PATTY and (5th, 2001), ICSC (1998), HSFS (2004), and SITTIG (47th, 2002)), and The Draize method test result in rabbit is "mild reaction" (ACGIH (7th, 2003)). On the other hand, there is a statement that the condition of an eye is recovered for a short times (PATTY (5th, 2001), GESTIS (2005)). It was set as Category 2B based on these information.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitization: Classification not possible; Skin sensitization: Classification not possible

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Since there was no information other than the negative result (IUCLID (2000)) of an in vitro mutagenicity test (reverse mutation test using bacteria), we presupposed that we could not categorize it according to the technical guideline.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Although there is data of rat and mouse, an administration period is unknown. Therefore, it cannot be classified since data is insufficient.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 2 (central nervous system); Category 3 (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (central nervous system); May cause respiratory irritation or may cause drowsiness and dizziness (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: A statement that there is respiratory irritation in humans (ACGIH(2003), HSFS (2004)) and a statement that a central nervous systems is affected (ICSC (1998), HSFS (2004), SITTIG (47th, 2002)). So it is classified into Category 2 (central nervous system) and 3 (respiratory irritation).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (respiratory organs, liver) through prolonged or repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 (respiratory system, liver) based on the statement that there is a risk of doing a damage to respiratory systems and liver in humans (HSFS (2004), SITTIG (47th, 2002)) .

aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
aspiration_hazard.rationale: We classified it as Category 2 based on the statement that there is a risk of chemical pneumonia in case of swalloed by aspiration into the lungs (ICSC (1998)), and the statement that of risk of chemical pneumonia by intake (SITTIG (47th, 2002)). Since it was unknown whether it is the description based on human case, We did not classify it as Category 1.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It carried out the outside of Category from 48-hour LC50=110000microg/L of Crustacea (Brine shrimp) (AQUIRE, 2003).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since not water-insoluble (aqueous solubility =30900 mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)) and acute toxicity is low.
